interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

div.title: Lorg an Ogain
div.p:
Bho AonasAonghas Mac AonAonaisAonghais aois craoitear
Smearcleit UistUibhist a Chinne Deas. Sgiobhta 13s
Gearrain (JanyJanuary) 1865. Ath-sgriobhta 12 NovNovember 1870
Bho leabhar Aireamh II duileag 19.

Bha fear tighinn a chur draogh air an Fheinn
agus a ghoid a bhithidh orra. Cha robh sian fios
aca (aig an Fheinn) co bha ris an draogh agus 'sann
thuirst gille nan con aig Fionn gum fuireadh
easan aig an taitaigh as a bheinn shealg lalatha agus
gum faiceadh e co bha ris a mhearla. 'S e
so a raoin Gille chon Fhinn agus co bha ris
an draogh ach fuamhaire mor. Lean
Gille chon Fhinn eir a luirg e agasu mharbh
se e.

lg.l: Lorg an Ogain seach an t-àth
An ceum rò mhath tha so dhian
Lorg an Ogain seach an t-ath
An ceum rò-mhath tha ro dhian
Cha'n e nighean Locha-luinn
S chan e Diarmad an miog ghlain
S cha be h-aon a chuideacchuideachd Fhinn
Dh-imich an raoir san troma ghleann

div.title: Lorg an Ogain

lg.l: Thruis mi m c eideadh s thari mi as
Feadh na mointeach bu gharbh dreis (?treis)
Sann a sin a rug mi eir
Ann am beinn bhig eadar' a sgán
Dh-faraidDh-fharaid mi dhé gu foil
Ach fhir mhoir cait mar sin?
Ach fhir bhig sin 's ach fhir bhig
Ga do dh faraiddh fharaid cha bu ghlic
An Fheinn uile cha b fuilleirb fhuilleir dhuit
Thoirt a shloinneadh an aon duine.
An Fheinn uile nan tugainns ann
creibh An creibh slan cha bhi'dh ad chotain
A chuid nach pronnadh iad len la'un
'S dearbh gu loisgeadh iad le'n anail
F Sin far an do thilg e orm
An t-sleagh mhor a bha na dhorn

lg.title: Lorg an Ogain
lg.l: S gun deach i siar seac traighean
Trom ann is talamh
Sin gur na thilg mi eir
An crann beag a bha fom shail
S gun deach e siar romh chri
S gun deach e siar romh chri
S gur h-ann diusa s measa sin
Nach d' raoin thu do shloinneadh o chianaibh
Mun tug (gille) ceannar st coin Fhinn
Nach d' raoin thu do shloinneadh o chianaibh
Mise Siain (Seathain) mac Righ Beirt (Bergen)
Mac an fhir eide mhoir ghairbh
S gun b' ainm dhomh tighinn gu teach
Ceannarst nan coig ceudaibh con.
Lorg an Ogain seach an t-àth
An ceum an ròthaidh(?) tha ro-dhian.

div.title: Lorg an Ogain

lg.l: 2 Rann. "Cha n'e nighean Loch-a-linne
'S cha ne Diarmad an uisg ghlain."

div.p:
Bha nighean do Righ Lochlan na mnaoi aig
fear do mhuinntir na Feinne agus bha ceann
coise frasach mor aice. Thatar ag rathain
nach robh neach 'san Fheinn aig an robh cas
cho mor 'sa bha aig a bhoireannach so ach
aig Diarmad mac Righ Duinnich a
mhian Diarmad donn nan con. 'S e meud
cas Dhiarmaid tha na facail ann an LaoiLaoidh
Dhiarmaid a ciallachadh far am bheil iad ag rath-
Mac Righ Duinne bu trom troigh, no thosd.

Airiste le Donnacha Mac Illiallain Donnacha Bān aois
clachair agus craoitear Carnan
IocarIochdar UistUibhist a Chinne Deas. Sgriobhta 10mh
Gearrain (Jany.January) 1865. A' sgriobhta 12mh NovNovember 1870.
bho Leobhar aireamh I duileag 17

lg.l: Lorg an Ogain seach an t-àth
Ceum an rothaid 's e ro-dhian
Lorg an Ogan seach an t-ath
Ceum an rothaid se ro dhian
Gui'mid (Gui'eamsa) eir laimh nam Fiann
'S cha be Fionn fhein no Oisein.

div.title: Lorg an Ogain

lg.l: 'S cha be Niall a' Loch-a-linne
'S cha b'e Diarmad an uisge ghlain.
'S cha b'e h-aon a chuideacchuideachd Fhinn
'Dh-imich a raoir san troma ghleann
Thruis mi m aodach s thar mi as
Eir garbhlaich bu gharbh treis
Bha mise uam ruith s nam leum
S bha m Fiar mor na chruaichruaidh cheum
Am beinn bhig eadar dha sgain
Sann a sin a rug mi eir
S dh-faraiddh-fharaid mi dhe gu fè 's gu foil
Fhir mhoir nach dean thu do shloinneadh?
Ach fhir bhig sin us fhir bhig
Ga do dh-faraiddh-fharaid cha bu ghlic
Gu m feumadh tu'n Fheinn uile
Thoirt a shloinneadh an aon duine

div.title: Lorg an Ogain

lg.l: An Fheinn uile nan tuainn ann
An creibh cha bhi'eadh slan ad cholain
Chuid nach loisgeadh iad le'n anail
S dearbhadh gum pronnadh iad le'n lamhun.
Sann a sin a chith e orm
An t-sleagh mhor a bha na dhorn
Gu'n deachaideachaidh i seachad siar
SeacSeachd traitraigh diag fo'n troma thalamh
Sann a sin a chaith mi air
An gath beag a bha fo'm shàil
S gun deachaideachaidh e staigh romh chrichridh
S leum an t-oigear lan fuil mhear.
Sann duisa b' aireach fhir mhoir
Nach d' raoin thu do shloinneadh a dheanadh chianaibh
Mu'n tug gille cinn coin Fhinn
CoragComhrag dhiort anns an troma-ghleann
S mise Seathain mac Righ Buirt
Mac an fhir mhoir eide gharbh

div.title: Lorg an Ogain

lg.l: Se b' ainm dhomh tighinn gu teach
Ceannarst eir choig cheuda chon.
S gu'n thilg mi mo shleagh eir lar
S thomhais mi n t oigear eir thraighean
S bha seacseachd traighean ann eir liad
Sa ceithir diag ann eir fad
Lorg an ogain seach an t ath –
Ceum an rōidh us e ro-dhian.

div.title: Laoidh Na h-Ighinne
div.p:
Bho Phatrig Smith – "Patra mac Aonais", ic
Dhonil ic Phatrig – Craoitear eir an Leth-mheadh
anaich, Baoghastal mu Dheas Uist D.Uibhist a Deas 24/4 1869.
Aois an fhir-airis 70. Alex.Alexander A.Archibald Carmichael
Deilbh na sgeul – ‘Thainig an inghean eir thearm-
ad thun na Feinne agus i teicheadh romh mhacan
mor Righ Na Sorach. Shiu'ail i gach ait eir
toir na FinneFeinne eirson iad ga a cumail bho
Mhacan mor mac Righ Na Sorach. Cha robh
daoine 'sam bith cho gaisgeil ris an Fhinn
eir son dion lucluchd ainearstainnearst agus nan lag
lamhach' Seanachaidh.

lg.l: LaLatha dhuinn eir bheagan sluaigh
Aig Eas-rua ri eigin mall {nan eadhan chrann nan eadhan chrann
Chunnacas a teurnadh o'n ear // lear
Currach mor corr agus bean ann.
Dh-eirich iad uile gu dian
Mochad, Fionn as Iall as Goll
{Shealltuin Choimhead a churraidh (churraich?) a b fhearr ceumgleus.
Bean {na dheireadh da reimhich ri sgoltadh thonn.
Aithne cha d' rinn iad ach tosd
Ghabh ad i cal sa-eir, phorst ghnath
lg.title: Laoidh Na h-Ighinne
lg.l: Thainig i nuas eir an eas
Thainig aiste mac-e-mnē. mna
B'ionnan {dearsadealradh dhi 's don ghrein
Bu leoir a min as gach dealbh.
Bean ur a thainig oirnn an cein
Bha sinn gu leir roimpe soirbh.
Dh-ionnuichiomaich (imich?) i gu pobul Fhinn
S ì bhean i bu ghrinn doigh
Fhreagair Mac Cumhail gu binn o thuim
Le' a ghuth binn gu min 's gu foil.
Dh-fharaid an Righ bu ro-ghlan fios (slios?)
Ciad failt eir 'n ighean ghlan ur nan ciabh òr
Miste sinn fhaoighneacfhaoighneachd a nis
'N e siud am fear a th'eir a thus? thoir?
'S daimhin liom-a-sa siod Fhinn
Ga cumha 's ga tiomtinn leat a (e?)
Gu'n tairg e mise thoirst leis
Ga mor a bheacbheachd as an Fheinn

div.title: Laoidh Na h-Ighinne

lg.l: Blianna dhē (i?) bhi am pobul Fhinn
Gu su'ach agus gu minn dō
Chunnacas an steud eir an leirg
'S an rod chiad a rinn a bhean
Bha chlaichaidheamh trom toirsteil nach gann
Teannt an laimh an fhir-mhoir
Bha chlogada teannta mu cheann
Bha chlogada teannta mu cheann treoir treoir
Dh-eirich Fearghus a ghloir fir
Geasun a chuir e nar ceann
Nach reacha tu leis mar mhnaoi
Ga mor a ghniomh agus àgh.
Thainig an laoch bu ro-ghlan dreach
Le' chriochun 's le nearst nan ceann
Gu'n dh-fhuada rich e uainn a bhean
Bha ri cala (cara?) gualain Fheinn
Thilg e mac Morna an urachair threun
Gu teann as a dheigh le shleagh
Cha d bhŏin an urachair dha chre
Ach rinn i a sgeith na da bhloigh

div.title: Laoidh Na h-Ighinne

lg.l: Thilg an tOscar bu trom fearg
A chraoslach dhearg á 'laimh chli
Is leagadar steud an fhir dheis –
Is mor am beud a chinnich leibh leinn
An trath leagadar thuit an steud eir an leirg
Thionndai e le feirg 's le fraoch
CōragCōmhragTairgeadar ga bu mhor an toirst
CoragComhrag nan trieir an eir an {caogad {500= laoch
An tuma (?) dhiom s ga m athair fhein
ChaiChaidh ceud nach tiom 's bu trom treun na dhail
Cha ro h-aon a thainig as
Nach ro'n crioslach lan chreucchreuchd
Blianna dhaibh s gu'n (mu'n) ghlac ad arm
Aig laoch garg ri sathadh shleagh
Ga'n teagasg am Pobul Fhinn
S ga n leigheas aig Fionn nam Fleagh
Dh-eirich Goll an aigne mhir
A liodairst an fhir a bha anns s an rod
Ga b'e chi'eadh iad a sin
Bu gharbh an goille 's an scleo.

div.title: Laoidh Na h-Ighinne

lg.l: Bha clainean aca ri soc
A snaidheadh clioth chlogad is sgiath
An t-altinneal-coraigcomhraig bh' aig an dist
Cha'n fhacas roimhe us rist riabh.
Chlaoi mac Morna le 'laimh chli
Mac Righ na Sorach is geuir arm
'S meinig dha'n treabhtreubh dha'n taine bhean
Leis na thuit an fear o'n chuan.
Thiol'aic sinn ri taobh an Eas
Gille nan cleas bucorr mhor pris
Chuir iad ma bhre’ad gach meoir
Fain oir mar onair ri mnaoimhic righ
S e m'athair fhe bu ro-ghlan cliu
Cha do dhiult e run do na treud
S an nist o n deireadh dham' laoi
Gur cumha liom suim mo sgeul
Tha sgeul beag agam eir Fionn
Th Ga b e chuireadh an suim e
S mise n ighean Righ fo Thuinn
Inseam duit a Righ mo dhan
Cha rorobh sgriobh mun iadh grian
Tha gabh m fheoiri ? eir muir
Laoch is is mor guin eir mo lorg
Mac Righ na Sorach is geuir arm
Mac ad dha'n ainm oighre borb
Chunnacas an steud eir an leirg
'S an rod chia’n a rinn a bhean
S e a iomairst a chleasun mora gu dian
S e tighinn an driminibh a chuain.
Bha ciad cleas gaisgich na lagh
Eir bhuirbead eir ghaisge eir ghoil
Na'm faight air caramh a sgiath
Chan fhacas riabh neach mar e
Bha chlogad n teannt mu cheann
Air laoch bu tiom 's bu treun
Sgiath dhriminne nach teid eir ais
O imileag gu cneas a chleibh
S e tighinn chugain chum na tuinn (tuin?)

div.p:
Patrick Smith heard this lay from
42 years ago from Rua'raidh mor Mac-a-Phiocair
from Airi-mhic-rury North Uist. Mac-a-Phiocair
lived at Leth mheadhonach for a year then for a
two years at Baoghastal whence he went to Cape
Breton. He had much old lore.

div.title: Laoidh Oscair
div.p:
Bho Phatric Smith Leth-meadhonach, Uist Deas.
24 April 1869. AlxAlexanderA.ArchibaldCarmichael
Deilbh agus aobhar na laoi[dh]

Bha Oscar no Osgar na oganach fia[t]hach laidir agus
cha robh doigh mharbhaidh eir ach an aon
doigh. Bha oil aig Coirbre Ruadh mac Righ
Eirinn a mharbhadh agus thug e air a phiuthar
fhein a phosadh los gum faigheadh i mach
fios eir an seol marbhaidh a bha eir. Rinn
i seo – phos nighean Righ Eirinn Osgar agus
mar a bhios na mnathainn a diurais ris an
fir fhuair e mach o Osgar bu de bu sheol
marbhaidh dha. Thainig an Coirbe Ruadh am
foil eir a phiuthar agus faighear a mach uaipe
seo. "Chan eil seol marbhaidh orms orsr an
t-Osgar aluin ach le m shleagh fhein agus
chan eil neach is urrain a h-oibreachadh gus
am fas i geal." Chuala Coirbre seo Togar ceard-
ach fo n talamh. agus Shir agus fhuair e iomlaid
sleigh bho'n Osgar a cur am fiacha gun rorobh e dol
a thoirt blar do dhuthaich nam Fear Mora
Thug Osgar a shleagh do Choirbr duair bha e
dol a chall ri fear eile. Chuir Caribr an t-sleagh
sin fios eir Osgar gu cath. Thainig Osgar
Laoidh Oscair Ruith Coirbre mach le sleigh Osgair agus
I geal le teas agus sheol e i troimh chorp Osgair

lg.l: Ceithir chiad do-fheara bogha
Thainig oirnn – 's cha b' ann gar cobhair
Thuirt siod le laimh Osgair thall
ChaiChaidh mhasladh gu righ na h-Eirionn
Ceithir chiad do fheaibh Catha (feacfeachd?)
Thainig oirnn o thir an t-sneact-sneachd
Thuirt siod le lamh Osgair etc
Ceithir ciad a dh-fhearaibh mora
Thainig oirinn o thir nan leomhna
Thuit siod le laimh Osgair thall
ChaiChaidh a mhasladh gu Righ na Eirinn
'S ann a sin a thainig Fionn
Eir an tulaich os ar cionn
Shileadh e na deoir os ach
Shill e na deoir eir a rasga
Mo laogh fhein thu laogh mo laoigh thu
Leana mo leanaibh ghil chaoimh thu
Mo chrichrith gal riut mar lúin
Se mo chreach chradh nach eirich Osgar
Se mo chreach chradh nach eirich Osgar
Chuir thu cath eir na ceudan
Reacha na corun romh' chrios
lg.title: Laoidh Oscair
lg.l: Si mo lamhsa min do leaghas
Mo leaghas cha neil e bhos
Cha mhu dh eireas mi gu brach
Chuir Cairbe sleagh ann seang
Eadar m imleag agus m airnean
Sann a shaoil mi roimhe riabh
Nach chrichrith feola bh’ ann am chliabh
Ach chrichrith do ghuinne? Cuillinn
Sin a theannachadh le stailinn
Comharstaich uan con ri m thaobh
Agus buirich nan sean laoch
Gaīsich nam ban
Siod an rud a ghom chraidh mo chrichrith
Sin nuiar a thog 'ad an t-Osgar aluin
Eir bharra sleagh s eir ghuala arda
Bha iad ag iomaracha grin
Gus na rainig ard taigh Fhinn leis
Osgar mac Oisein an aigh
A thog an seacseachd cloiche bho'n lar
Chuir e fararui (Cairbre?) a mach
An gniomh mu dheireadh am cheud mhac

div.p:
Smith thinks he heard this lay from
a "Niall RuaRuadh" – Niall DonnullachDomhnullach, Leth meadhon-
ach an old man of 75 who died 20 years ago.

div.title: Cha Teid Mor a Bharraidh.
div.p:
From Peigi NicNeill, Brutharnis Barraidh
30 SepSeptember 1870

Bha Nighean Alasdair Ruaidh an
UistUibhist agus Nic an Fhinn am Barraidh
Bhiodh an distdithist daonnan a coinneach
agus a caineadh a cheile. Chuala Nic-
an-Fhinn gu robh luathadh gu bhi
ann an Cille bhride agus chuir i oirre
luireagann us banlagann agus cairear
oirre gu ruig UistUibhist . Thainigeas a shir-
eadh na clainn erighean dha'n taigh
s an robh Nic-an-fhinn a tamh agus thuirt
a chlann nighean nach readh iadsan
chun an luthaidh mar readh a
bhan stranger co sin. Dh-fhalbh
Nic-an-Fhinn leo agus suidhear suas
ri taobh Nighean Alasdair RuaiRuaidh. Thig
Nic-an-Fhinn dhi na barlagann agus
na luirsagainn as sheinn i rann
air an rann ris Nighean Alast-
air RuaiRuaidh. Cha rorobh fios co i
div.title: Cha Teid Mor a Bharraidh.

lg.l: Fonn – Cha teid Mor a Bharraidh bhronach
Fonn – Cha teid Mor a Bharraidh bhronach
Cha teid Catrina gada deoin ann
Na AnaAnna bheag ma's i is oige
Far am bi na sgait eir fleotra
Langain gan tarruin eir ropa
Gur e strubain is biadh loin daibh
Daleagan is Suileāun-mora
Muarsgain gun draothadh a lointibh
Sg
Ceum na dh-fhairid thun i bu bheo mi
Tha mo theanga sosair conart
Chaidh i ri cloich eir mhon-de
Cha bi mo thir an tir
Ca na shuid i eir a cota
Nighean tighearna na toisich
Gad bhiodh i eir a h-oradh
O mhullach a cinn gu brogan
B' airi Gilleonain og oirre
Gaisgeach eir sliocsliochd nam fear mora
Nighean caillich dhuibh na h-otraich
Nighean dearg mheirlich na feola
BheiredhBheireadh eir na luingis seoladh
lg.title: Cha Teid Mor a BharraiBharraidh

lg.l: An aodan na beinne Di-domhnaich
Is truagh nach robh thu seal eir m' ordain
Slaoda ris an tur eir coirdeal/ corcaich
Us da shac diag eir teien moine
Us da fhear 'iag a dh-fhearaibh mora
Us bradag eadraeadarra ga rosadh
Na mucan bhi g itheadh a feola
S na coin mhora bhi gad spotha
Cha bibhi mo thir an tir bhronach
Tir a choirce, an t-seagail 'us eorna
Tur uisge beatha agus feoraich (beoirich?)
Gheobhadh Eirionnaich an leoir ann
Na m fonadh muc us feoil daibh
Dh-fhasadh peas air ann 'us ponair
Dh fhasadh lian (liut) na chruach orbhin
Dh-fhasadh barra-ban eir an coudain (tu-foil)
Gillean futheaili deas eolach
Ga chuir thuc ann an ordain.

div.p:
Thuirt a bhan UisteachUibhisteach eir
a chlia-luathaidh Togaibh suas a
chailleach agus cuiribh cailleach eile
na h-aite siud orsa Nic-an-Fhinn.
Cha be teic do Nic an Fhinn fhein
sid a dheanadh orsa na mna cleithe
div.title: Cha Teid Mor a Bharraidh.

lg.l: Is mise Nic-an-Fhinn, ban eileannach
Cailleach spogach ainneach
Tha bus thar corr 's tha beilleas orm
'S tha baobh dearg mo sheiche muigh.

div.p:
Thainig a sin cairdean Nighean
Alasdair RuaiRuaidh a thoirt a mach a toiseactoiseach
agus b-fhearr dh'an bhan Bharrach teicheadh.
Thug i mullach Hartamal oirre. Len lucluchd
a torractorrachd i ach le toabh dearg seiche mairt
a bhi mach oirre s an a theich iad roimpe
Thug Fear Bhaghasdail £5 di agus
chuir e eathar luths gu ruig Barraidh.
Bhiodh Nic-an-Fhinn a faicinn na
BardacBardachd falbh roimpe eir bharr an
fhraoich agus cnescneas nan tonn. Is i ban
Oileanach (=eileanach) a bh innte a
mhuintir Mhiulaidh (=Miuley)
Bha i eir leth geur deas chainnteach

div.title: Is Toileom S Toileam.
div.p:
From Iain Macneill aois 76

S toileom chuinne-chas geala chas lua chas

S toileom Ruarai 'dhireadh glean
Ho hi run, ho hi u o

Aoilte ruaidh 's do ghunna snaip eir ghleus

Ho hi run ho hi u o
Ho hi run, ho hi u o

Ho hi run ho hi u o

Oran Iain oig mhic 'Ic Neill Bharraidh
Is i mhuime rinn an t oran so da.
Thainig an toir eir Iain og agus rug-

agus biorann iaruin troimh na clair

The song is said to have been composed
by his wife – a daughter of Macleod
of Harris – to Clanranald from whom
she became estranged. She went home
to her father's house where she lived for
a time

div.p:
Bho Iain Pearson coitear Ceann-

lg.l: Giullan gealū gealū gealū

M' inean (anam?) 's mo run
Dhireadh tu 'n stuc
Gill eir a chul

div.title: Giullan Gealù

lg.l: M' ineanMo charraig' s mo chiall // My rock and my reason.
An t-Ailpeineach ciar Thou dark-haired Ailpeineach
{Gun eir do sgiath A bow on ther end a targe

'S tu fiadhach bheann And thou deer-stalker on the
mountains.
M' aighear us m' uaill
Mo chobhrachan cuain

S ruadh air a mhaing!
Mu'n taine Leodach a dh-Alba
Bha na seoid ud a seanachais
Bha (n) ceann feadhna ainmeil

Their cacha nach e am bocain
{Dh-fhagChuir an nocnochd iad cho gann
M' inean 's mo chiall
An lasgaire fiall
Dhire tu n sliabh
'S tu fiadhach bheann.

div.p:
Note. The Ailpeinich and the Macinnons
are said to be of the same treubh (tribe)
and to be very old among the our oldest treubha.
Cnuic us sluic al uillt us AilpeinichArtaraich
Ach cuin a thainig Ailpeinich.
div.note:
Copy of this sent to Mrs Ry Rhys London
for her collection of lullabys of all countries.

div.title: Eolas Beum Sula
div.p:
Bho Iain Pearson, coitear Ceann-
tangbhal, Barraidh Diluan DecrDecember 1870.

lg.l: Dianaieinse duitsa eolas eir suil
A ucuchd 'Ille Phadruig naoimh
Eir at a'aich us eir stad earbail
Eir naoi {conneir {connait 's air naoi conachair
'S eir naoi naodha bean seanga sith
Ma's a suil fir i, i a lasadh ma bhī
Mas a suil mnai i, i bhith dh-easbhui a cich
Falcadair fuar agus fuarac da fuil
Eir a crodh, eir a caoirich
Eir a daoine 's eir a cuid.

div.title: Clann an Lir

lg.l: Ceann a bha sinn an a Chlann an Lir
Mar teid air neobh neomh=rereamh gur bruth chlaon
(Mur teid ar neo-bhrith breith chlaon?)
Aona Mhic De gu'n teid Aoidh.
A chleirich theachaid an uaigh
Cairich Fiachir 'us Conn cruaicruaidh ri m thaothaobh
Cairich eadar mo dha laimh
A chleirich aigh cairich Aoidh

div.note: Hector Maciosaig Eachann Mac Ruairi – Ceannlangabhat IocarIochdar SSouth Uist 4th April 1872.
div.p:
This was said to cleireach a chaidh
when digging the grave of Clann an Lir
on the shore of Larne Ireland. Clann
an Lir were put under spell where they
remained for three hundhundred years in the guise of
swans. There were three brothers and a
sister under enchantment. They were
one hundred years on Maol na h-Os
(Islay?) and one hundred years on
Maol Ghallabhagh. There were not a
night ashore all this time except one
night on – An Carra-Sgiathach where
they left their primaries from from
the hard frost

Their muime stepmother with her
geaslauc enchantment put their child-
ren of Leir under enchantment and they
went away in the likeness of swans. Their
desconsolate father who was greatly attach-
ed to them then built a bothag (bothy) close
to the shore of the water. Although in the likness
of swans the children used to come at
night and nestel on their fathers breast
and under this arms all night long.
div.note:
From Hector Macleod –
"Eachann Mac Alastair" –
Lianacui IocarIochdar SSouth Uist
11th April 1872
div.title: Clann an Lir
div.p:
Mac-an-Lir was the name of the father
ultimately his wife repented and S rug
"Mac-an-Lir" na chlithin chro
Is more urchair s leir dha shleag
Is bocbochd liom orna an t-seann laoich
Ge do 's mise thoill da fhearg."

It was at the side of Loch dearg
in Eirinn that Mac-an-Lir had his
bothag. The swans were there for 100
years and for 100 years on Loch-
neathach in EirinEirinn and 100 years
on Maol Chinntire. When the
swans came to Ceanntire a storm
separated the femal female sawn – an eala
bhoirionn – from her brothers. Then
forst and snow and "gaillionn" set
in and she took shelter by the side
of Carn-na Sgiathaich where she
left her long wing feathers hard in the
forst. Carn-na-Sgiathaich is so called
from the cirumstances.

lg.l: Gur tusa gaire na h-eala nocnochd
Gur tusa fo torrun na
Gu'n uisge lionnar fo'n ucuchd
An cuilp gam bualadh
lg.title: Mac-an-Lir
lg.l: Gun uisge lionnar tlach treun
Gun tonn mara tighinn ri n taotaobh
'Nuair threig an muir meo'rach mor
Nach laidh le'n caoin.

div.p:
When going home the children
passed the bothy of their father now a
help of nettles – na thorr eanndag –
and the sister sang.

lg.l: An t-ionad so chunna mi roimhe
(Bha) ol ann aighear us aoibhneas
Na thorr eannd gun solus gun soillse
When they reached the grave

div.p:
When they reached the grave
she sang and for the last time –

lg.l: A chlerich chladhaich an uaigh
Cuir Iachai agus Conn ri m taotaobh
'S a chleirich ghrai carich a Aodh.

div.p:
Clann an Lir were buried together
in Eaglais Phadruig an EirinEirinn.

In Irish history these children of Lir are called
Conn, Faicra Finnghuala and Aodh. Their
story along with the storyof the Children of Tuireun
and the children of Uinse are the three tragic
stories of Ireland. See TransTransactions Gaelic Society
Dublin 1808 page 12 of Irish. A.AlexanderC.Carmichael

div.title: Is Ann A Ghabh Mi Mo Chead
div.p: From Catrina Pearson bocag Ceann- tangbhal BarraiBarraidh 23 March 1871

According to the seanachai this song
was composed by a daughter of Mac-
neill of Barra to or rather a daughter
of Donald son of Macneill, to James
the first of the Clanranalds who
got Boisdale after the Macneills.

Donald son of Macneill was
married to Fionnaghal mhor
daughter of Clanranald and sister
to the Clanranald who fell at Sheriff
-muir shot dead it is said in Uist
by the only son of a widow whom
he forced into his army. Her father
had only a life rent of Benbecula and
so his people would not allow James
to marry Seonaid (Ni Mhicneill)
as she had no land. James married
a daughter of his maternal uncle –
Mor Ni Ruarai na h-ErradhEarradh.
Seonaid Ni Mhicneill BharraiBharraidh
went to Ireland where she married
the son of E Iarl Antrim Earl of Antrim.
div.title: Is Ann A Ghabh Mi Mo Chead

lg.l: S ann a ghabh mi chiad dhiot
A cheist nam fear oga
Man do chuir iad mi dh-Eirinn
Ann an nionaig bhig oig / cheisteig
O! dianamid misneach / gabhasuid
Se gliocas is coir
Gur a farsuinn an saoghal
G Falero! falero! falero fal i

Is glan an dears tha na d' ao'n
Och is och mar a tha mi
S mi an tras ga d shior chaoi smaoin
Is leat mise mar ghealaich
Is leat mise mar ghrian
Is leat mise mar caill mi
Na bheil agam am chiad
Ga boil leis a chaillich

lg.title: Is Ann A Ghabh Mi Mo Chead
lg.l: Ach a Dhouil nan D'oul
Gur a bronach mi d' dheigh
Led chul camalagach dualach
'Us e na cluaicheinean rē
Cha n eil{Far bheil og bhean s na {glinnibhgleannach / thalamh
Nach {tugadhtoireadh duit speis – geil

Gun chaistneacchaistneachd gu'n stri

div.title: Dhuisg Mo Leannan Mi
div.p:
From Duncan Macdonald aged 86
crofter Snaisebhal South Uist 28th
March 1871. A.Alexander Carmichael

Story – There was once a young and beauti-
ful girl girl in South Uist and she and
the son of a neighouring crofter were
greatly attached to one another. He would
not be allowed to marry her and was being
forced into a marriage with another – a
girl of means. When this sensitive and
beautiful girl said that she was losing
her lover she went wrong in the mind.
She escaped from her parentscul-taigh home and fled
to the hills, agus, gu'n sgòd aodaich oirre
ach a leine – she ran with rapidity. All
the neighbours were after her best to no pur-
pose. She joined the deer in Benmore and
moved about with them whereever they went.
And strange to say the deer did not
flee from her but on the contrary seemed
to be not afraid of her. She wanted the
hills with the deer and lay down and
slept in their midst. Various attempts
were made to capture hre but in vain.
div.note:
Sorcha an Orfhuilt A Chaidh Fiadhain Eir Na Feidh
Clara of the Golden Hair That Went Wild With The Deer
div.title: Dhuisg Mo Leannan Mi
div.p:
At last her broken hearted parents said to her
young man – "Go and shoot her rather than
that she should thus be a heart breaks us." And
the young man went away to the hills &resolving never
to come back without her living or dead. He
tried many times to get near her but in vain.
He was away one day though Benmore and
when he came back at night to his {bothaguamh, cave bothy he found
her sound asleep on the floor of his bothy. He
was afraid of her but being strong and brave
he resolved to grapple with her. He touched her gently
and she sprang to her feet he locking his arms
round her her waist at the same moment. She
look at him gently but made no attempt
to move. She then sang this hymn to him
and immediately after gently died in his arms.

He gently laid her down on the floor of the
hut and covering her body over with his
plaid – plaide – he ran away home for
assistance. ButBy the time he reached home
he was so done up with exhaustion of mind and
body carrying the bruthen of the fair girl on
his back and on his heart that he laid himself
down to die. He told how he got her the
hymn she sang and having kissed him
Dhuisg Mo Leannan Mi that she died in his arms. He
was dead before morning. Bha an da
thorradh 'san aon latha agus thiochaidh
an tiolachadhtiodhlacadh taobh ri taobh anns an aon
uaigh ann an cladh.

Duncan Macdonald, an in-
teresting, intelligent old man, says that
this story is true and that the thing really
happened much as he has narrated it.

lg.l: Dhuisg mo leannan mi am chadal
'Us mi gabhail fadail {am dhusgaas innis

l.del: Gus mo fheumail an tuis e

lg.l: Mi nam ghrioba 2 ri garadh x gnobha =
A ni! bu narach {an tulu e a chuis e
Mi gu'n tuigse gu'n reusan
Gur neo-fheumail an tursa e
Siud a ghit tha mi sireadh
Rinn do spiorad nach uirnigh.
Is tus a Chrido tha 'sa chathair
Rinn an latha na uair domh

lg.l: Mis eir fasach a mhunaidh (mhonaidh)
Do bhlaths a cumail an fhuacfhuachd uam
Is ioma {rud{ni a ni d' fheatsa
Gu feol a pheacaich a ghluasad
A Dhe mun cuirear san uir mi
Cuir thr 'ús gliocas mu'n cuartcuairt domh.
AlAlternative A Righ man cuirear san uir mi
Cuir brigh do ghliocas mun cuartcuairt domh.
Is tu mo Tighearna priseil
Is tu mo spisniche (tagsa) laidir
Is tu mo thoplachan broslaich
ChaoiChaoidh na dealaich gu brath mi
Eir son nithere dimein
Eir sgath na fag mi
A Mhic Samhla na Greine
Lath m' eug bi-sa lamh rium
Gur laidir a mhisneach
Th' aig lucluchd bhriste na Sabai
Nach faodar ion an airbeadh.

div.title: Dhuisg Mo Leannan Mi

lg.l: 'S ann a bhithsbhitheas iad eir lothain
Mar na deomhan 'sa an {cheardach (?)
Agus tha Criosda gealltuin
Nach seall e gu brath on sin
Ge bu shinear na clacha –
Ge bu doinainean oir iad
Ge b' fhion uile an fhairge
An deis a dioladh le
Ge bu daimein an talamh
B annsa sealladh do Chriosd
Le sichainnt as trociar.
Iosa! sinn dian cobhar eir m' anam
Iosa a chomhdaich adnad ghradh mi-mhaite
Iosa glacas mo spiorad
An deis a dioladh le
Ge bu daimein an talamh
B annsa sealladh do Chriosd
Iosa sinsa domh do lamha! do lamh dhomh

div.p:
Note – The girl never spoke again after this but
having looked at herself and seeing that
she was wholly naked and having
kissed her lover she died in his arms –
from shame it is thought. Some say
that he brought her body on his back all
the way from Benmore to
div.title: Dhuisg Mo Leannan Mi
div.p:
Others that he spread his "plaide" over the body
and ran home for assistance and immediately
after died. There were three things for which the
girl was always spoken of in the place – her great
shyness her great modesty and her great beauty.
She was had always magnificent hair but
when going wild – am fiadhan – with the deer
it grew so long and thick that it covered
her body down to her knees.

The deer always slept in a cluster round her
and however much they were alarmed and
had they were in chased they always glanced
round to look for her unless she was in their midst when
indeed she invariably was. It is sadi that
think downy hair grew over her whole
body from the long exposure to the cold.

There are various versions of this story,
located in various places.

div.title: Taigh Mor Thunga
div.p:
From Roderick Macneill aged – Ruarai
mac DhouilDhomhnuill alalias "Ruarai an ruma" – from
a hogshead of rum he found on the shore and
from the contents of which he nearly died.
Miulaidh 22, May 1871. AAlexander Carmichael

Ruarai heard this from his father
who heard it in America where he had
been as leine-chneis with Macneill of
Barra during the America War.

Macneill and Ruarai's father lived to
come back to Barra after innumerable
and extraordinary escapes "hairbreadths
escapes by sea and land." Ruarai re-
membered many of these which he narrated
very circumstantially.

lg.l: Gu m beannaicheadh Dia Taigh mor Thunga
'S fhad o chualas
Rinn mac righ nam bratch ban
An aitreadh bhuadhach
Fhuair thu o dhaulachas do sheanar
Eir chuan Alba
Mar a rinn Connal Gulbach
Carraig-Fhearguis.

Nis on chuir a chleir at soiri
Dia gu'm beannaich

div.title: LaoiLaoidh Dhuill Liosadair
div.p:
From Cairistina nighean DuillDughaill (Nic Aonais)
Creag-goiridh Beinn a faothla 16 June 1876

Dughal Liosadair lived in Skye. He fell
in a trance in which he remained a long time.
When he came out of the trance he sang
this hymn.

lg.l: Cluinn a dhuine bith nad fhairil
Mun tuit cadal ort na dusal
Eisd am trump 'us thoir an aire
Guth nan ain ai'eal tighinn ad dhusga / dha
Ga socair thu eir a leabai
Cuimhnich gur h-aighear an uine
Ma tha curam ort ga t-anam
Eirich gu h-ealamh s ga t-uirnigh
Cha'n i 'n uirnigh ghoirid fhionnar
Cuimhnich a dhuine ni {feum{cuis duit
Ma tha curam ort ga t-anam
Gus an guil thu eir a shuilean

div.title: Iain Garbh
div.p:
From Mairi Nicrath, Caolas Stiatair Na h-ErradhEarradh
4 April 1876. Mairi says that she is close upon 100 years old.

lg.l: Gur a mise tha bronach gun ri leughadh a leo'rach
Fhuair mi naigheacnaigheachd s bu mhor liom a meud
Gun deach tu phosadh ri nighean Mhic an toisich
Ach gur mise b fhearr coir ort na i.
Siuthad oichoidhch agus latha cuir htu mi 'n ta'bhun
S beag a shaoil liom gu'n gabha tu m fhoil
S nach bu nar dhuit mi fhauim ann an thaothaobhdo leapa
S do leana beag altrum gun stri.
Gur mise tha bronach chuile latha Di-domhnuich
Gur beag m aighear ri posadh a chaoidh
Ach gur mis th' air mo sgarradh gu'n do bhat anns a chala
Do thaigh mor 's do thaigh talla gun dion.
Mar b'e dhomhs mar a tha mi agus bathadh gu'n bhata
Cha bu dana dhuit m fhagail s mi m theinn
Ach gur mise tha deurach mo thargai dha cheile
Ga na fhreagair thu na cu bha a tir.
Tha nial broin air a bhaile do lucluchd-taitaigh gu galach
Far am faighe lucluchd aitreach an diol

div.title: Iain Garbh

lg.l: Se mo ghaol na fir ghlana dh-fhalbh air thus an t-siuil mhara
Dh-fhalbh air thus an t-siuil mhara
Gan ro na beoil fharasda bhinn
Meangan fir froiseach
San liom gu'm b iomhuin a colas thar liom
ClaiClaidheamh curranta laidir
An deas lamh mo bhrathar
Sgiath bhreac nam ball ard a cli (chlì?)
Naile chuiinn mo chluas air
Nach eil fear eir am buaileadh
A throgadh bonn suasait a chaoidh
Iain oig 'IlleChalum
Ga'n tug mi 'n cionfalaich
Dh-fhag thu sinne nar carraid gun aoidh
Ach mu chaihd thu phùsadh
Nighean Tighearna n Dunain
Stric snithe le'm shuilean gu'n dion.
Gad is socrach mo leapa
Tha n oicheoidhche liom fada
Cha d fhuair mi n raoir cadal gu'n stri
Mi ri cumha Ruaraidh dh-fhag m inntinn fo luasgan
Ceud nan cuach chuir ga luaidh nam chrichridh

div.title: Eolas Beum Sula
div.p:
From Margaret Macintosh nee Campbell
wife of Donald Macintosh tailor South Boisdale SSouth Uist 14 Oct 1875

lg.l: Cuiri mis an oba so ri m shuil
Mar a dh-ordaich Righ nan Dul
A ucuchd Pheadair a ucuchd Phoil
An treas oba 's fearr fo'n ghrein.
Sil a Mhoire Sil a Dhia
Sil a Phadruig chaomh nan feart
S eir gach mac dha m math mu'n teid
Eir bhual larach s eir chruas lamha

Eir chath dearmud a uc an Athar 's a
Mhic agus an Spioraid Naoimh.

div.title: An Torranan
div.p:
From John Paton, Shepherd, a Skye Beaton or
Bethune, Ard-nan-laogh, S.South Uist

lg.l: Buainidh mise an Torranan
Le thorradh mara 's tir
Mar a dh-orduich righ nan Dul

Bainne chur an ūgh na ba s an cārr = udder; flesh
of seal
Le blioc le tlac 's le dair
Le laoigh bhoirionn bhreac
Gun aon laogh fiorionn ac.

div.note:
Note: The Torranan grows in one place in Benmore South Uist. It is like a
woman's pap and full of milk. Old Fionnaghal says that she would rather
than a pound note to have it as it would always secure her abundance.

"A bhannag", "A Pheigidh" no "a Mhor t anacair us
t easlaint a dh-fhalbh dhiot". Said by the oper-
ator at end of this Eolas. A snatheile is made for
a person water is thrown on a beast. The water
is a "tonn dhith" thrown on the beast and the
remainder on a cloich ghlais nach gluais!
The Eolas is made to a man by a woman
and to a woman by a man and to an
animal by either man or woman. It is
made to a man or beast upon whom
a "suil a luidh" suddenly! It comes
on as a vomit and yawning and a "greann
granda" An t Eolas Faireimeadh (quickly.)

The last part said three times over and when cutting the plant.
He used to swim to a small isle near him and bring from it three
roots which he twisted for the cuach three inches in diameter. The
mountain-ash – caorann is sented for the cuach and the
cidheann mu chrann-ivry."

lg.l: Le àgh 's le torradh
Gu'n fear mi-ruin
Gu'n mhadadh sgainteach
Gu'n chu fasaich a dh-fhaighinn greim
Air a chugain anns an teid so.
Torranan nan siunn
Torradh ga chur ann
Le al, le àgh, s le torradh.

div.note:
Note: "The Torrachan was placed in under the milk
basin in the milk-house. Old dairy-maids
had lots of gibeags about their milk." JJohn Paton.

Torranan – White as An Cannach – Cannach an t-sleibhe. The Canna
is seized. A woman made three shirts of it for her three brothers and then they
were fo gheasa an riocriochd feidh. The sister threw the shirts over their
horns and they were restored. It was their muime who put them fo gheasa
under skills. A.AlexanderC.Carmichael

div.title: An Eala-Bhì
div.p: From the same John Paton

lg.l: An Eala-bhi! s an Eala-bhi!
Mo niarach neach aig am bith
Buainidh mis i leis an laimh dheis
Paisgidh mis i leis an laimh chli
Ga b e chuire (gheobha?) tu ri cro an ail
Cha bhith e gu brath gu'n ni.

div.title: A Chloimh Chat

lg.l: Buainidh mise Chloimh-chat
An lion a bhuain Bride o (romh?) 'glaic
Air bhuaidh air luaidh s air thorradh
Air dhàir s air s chairr s air bhloghan
'S air laoigh bhreaca bhoirionn {gun arluth{bhailgneach

div.note: Note – This was put in milk.

lg.l: Thig na maoir, thig.
Thig na maoir 's thig na saoir
Thig fear a churraic bhuidhe
A chuireas am muighe na ruith buidhe na leum
Thig a (na) daora thig
Tha glug a so tha glag a so
Tha sulachag mhor bhog a so
Tha rud nach fhearr
Tha crag an duine mhairbh a so
Thig na maoir thig
Thig na maoir thig na saoir
Thig a storrach thig.

div.title: Coisrigeadh An Aodaich
div.p:
From Duncan Cameron Police Officer Lochaluinn
Morven 7th August 1886 – 'a man of great intelligence
and full of the old lore of the old Highland people.

Cuimhne, or cuinne, the heart, the head, antler
as Cuimhne an fheidh = Croic an fheidh. Brigh
do chuimhne air a comhdach le staillin." Laoidh
Oscair

lg.l: Is math a gha'as mi mo rann
A teurna leis a ghleann;
Aon rann, da rann t tre rann,
Cuithir rann, coig rann sia rann
SeacSeachd gu'n leth rann
Nar a ghonargonar fear an eidi
Nar a reubar e gu brath
Nuair a theid e'n cath no'n comhrag
(LomnocLomnochd an dom Domhnaich dha)
Biolair air a buian fo ?ro? lic
'S air a toirt do mhnaoi gu'n fhiost
Luig an fheidh an crann an sgadain
'S an caol chalp a bhradain bhric.
Is athadach so 's cha'n aoibh e (leibh?)
'S cha chuid cleir no sagairt e.

div.p:
The web is made into a roll. All the
women at the luadh work at the roll
and saying the rann three times over.
Then at the end the roll is tossed end over
end three times the women saying the which
Is athadach (?aodach) so s cha'n aoibh e.
The the roll is tossed back the reverse way,
the women saying:–
'S cha chuid chleir no sagairt e

Note – "Lurg an fheidh an ceann an sgadain,
'S an caol chalp a bhradain bhric."
A small bone in the head of the herring and
another in the Tail of the salmon are extremely
like the leg of a deer – hoof and all. The old people
were observant.

div.title:
Eolas an t-Sniamh (Sprain)=Sgiuchadh
=Siachadh

lg.l: Chaidh Criosda mach air maduin mhoich
Fhuair e cas nan each na spruileach mu seach
Chuir e cnaimh ri cnamh, feoil ri feoil,
Feithe ri feithe, fiona ri fiona
Smior ri smior, smuais ri smuais
Mar a leighis Criosda sin
Leighisidh e so. This is

div.p: This is said three times over the broken limb.

div.title:
An Eitheam mu Chrann. In Harris Leum
mu-chrann

lg.l: Buainidh mis an Eitheam mu chrann
Mar a bhuain Moire le h-aon laimh
Mar a dh-orduich Righ nan Dul
Bainne chur an uth s an carr
Le laoigh bhreaca bhoirionn bhailgneach
Air an laraich gu ceann fichead bliadhna
A ucuchd Dhia agus nan cumhacann comhla.
A bhean bhradach ud thall
Cuir a nall mo cheud bainn thugam!
LaLatha dhomh 's mi dol dha'n Roimh
Thachair orm Calumcille (Steaphain?) Peadair agus Pol
'S e cainnt a bh' aca 's a thachair bhi nam beul
Laoigh bhreaca bhoirionn bhailgneach,
Air an laraich gu ceann fichead bliadhna
An ainm Dhia s nan cumhacann comhla
A bhradag cuir dhachaidh mo bhainn thugam

div.p:
(You can keep your milk for ever with this (!).
The slatag (rod) is cut and a hoop cuach is made through
which your hand could go. Three leaves or sprigs
of ivy at equal distances are twined round the
coil and three broken horse nails are fixed in the
hoop and a broken horse shoe nail nailed above
the door through which the cows enter the byre.

Nothing under the sun can touch your
cows now!

This is then placed under the mios from
which it is never removed while the cow has
her milk.

div.title: Duan Callaig
div.p:
From Gilleaspa Dounallach Griasaiche Bailanloch
UistUibhist a Chinn a tuath 20 NovrNovember 1873

lg.l: Nist o thaine sinn an duthaich
A dh-urachadh dhuibh na Callaig
Cha ruig sinn a le[a]s bhi ga inns
Bha i ann ri linn ar seannar
A direadh air totatobhta
'S teurnadh aig an dorust
Mo dhuan a ghabhail gu modhail eolaich
Mar bu choir{nos omh (dhomh).
Caisein Callaig na mo phocaid
'S mor an ceo thig as an fhear ud
Cha n'eil ann a gheobh dheth aile
Nach bith gu brāch dheth fallain.
GheoGheobh fear an taighe na dhorn e
S cuiridh e 'shron anns an teallach
Theid e deiseil air an paisdean
S gu h araid gheo' a bhean e
Gheo' a bhean i o s i is fhiach e
Lamh a riarachadh na Callaig // bannag
O(n) thainig tart air an duthaich
S nach bith suilk aguinn ri drama
Rud beag do shochair an t-samhraidh
B fhearrde sinn leis an aran
Mar bheil sid againn ri fhaotain
Mu dh-fhaoteas tu na cam m'ait oirnn
Mis is doinis foasgail
A chullain seo a Challain seo.

div.p:
The lucluchd-callain went sun-wise three
times round the house. In Uist and others
of the isles where the walls of the houses are
wide the lucluchd]-callaig travelled round on
the walls of the houses to the number of
perhaps ten, twelve, or fifteen persons strick-
ing a hard dry cow-hide the while and
making a great noise – "making night
hedious" The hide was round the person
in front. The rest followed stricking at "the
monster."

On La-Fheil-Bride a person is sent
was sent to the strand to bring home a partan.
The partan was placed on the middle of the
house. If the partan went towards the
upper end of the house it induced that the family
remained on the laraich, site; but if the partan
went toward the door it induced that they were
to leave!

LaLatha Beoltainn there should be light showers
LaLatha-fheill-Pedair
LaLatha Lunastain
LaLatha Fheill Moire Mòire shearing and tying
LaLatha Samhna Goid a chail. Girls put cal
under the pillow. If a girl sees her lover talking
the cal from under her pillow she is to be
married to him that year.

Three plates, one of earth one of salt and
one of clean water are placed on the floor.

A girl is blind-folded and the plates are moved
about. The girl is then led to the plates into one of
which she places her hand – each place indicat
ing something, as the uir, earth, death'; the salt
bitterness = diolanas; and the clean water marriage!

The girls then throw their criosans belts
out through the opened window. A blind fold-
ed person throws them back one by one each girl
picking up her own crios as it came in. The
position in point of trim of the belt in the ceremony
indicated the position in point of the time of the owner's
marriage. If no belt could be found no marriage
See Burns The girls went to Allt criche a mach
stream, when they dipped their hands. They
were not to speak till spoken to in their sleep
and the speaker then was their lover

div.title: Tilgeil Ghloinneachain
div.p:
Clear water was put into a glass
The white of an egg – gealagan uibhe –
was gently let down. If the white rose
craobhach briagh it was forunate
if not, the reverse.
Salt drowning dirty water meant Diolanas.

A craobh chorc, an oat tree-stalk
was drawn out of a stack by the teeth.
The number of grains remaining in-
dicated the number of children. If the
top grain –"graine mullaich"–was off
the person died.

Càthadh an Fhras Lìn. The lint seed
was winnowed in the, "comh-ràth, dusk
The was done at Draoineach Skye
by a servant girl in the house. The wife
of Draoineach asked the girl whom did
she see and the girl answered that she
had no luck that the only saw her
master. Well you shall have him yet said
her misterss. The mistress died soon after and before
the year was out Fear na Draoinich married
this young girl!

Salt Herrings were eaten after having been roasted
on the fire. The person seen coming to give a drink
was the person to whom the girl was to be married.

"Co sid shuas air ceann mo ropain" A
girl threw a ball of thread – "ceaisle shnath"
into the soin of the kiln." Killogie in the
dark. The person who answered to the name
was the p man to whom the girl was to be
married.

On one occasion this had a serious effect
A bevy of bright girls were on their way in
the dark to the Kiln to go through this performance
Some young men watched them and got in
to the Kiln before them and one of them into the
Soin-Kilogie. The first girl threw in her
ball of thread and called out Co sid shuas
air ceann an ropain"? Answering a false
voice the young man answered accordingly to the
girls' wishes. Then another girl as[ke]d the same and
got a satisfactory answer. Then the third girl
threw in her ball and called out "Co sid shuas an
Ceann mo ropain"? "I am, the devil, come
To take you away for teaching these goslings my
secrets"! The poor grilgirl got such a fright that
she died from the effects of it soon thereafter.
It was in vain that the young man explained
to her and implored her forgiveness; the mis-
chief was done

div.title: Duan Na Muthairne
div.p:
From Duncan Maclellan, crofter, Carnan
South Uist 17thJanyJanuary 1874

lg.l: Duan na muthairn
A Righ na greine
Is aille aluinn do ghnuis
Da lub iarainn sios ri d' shisrich
Mhinich chraicinn

div.p:
Easgann an buidhe agus dolach no
dorlach as gach sathadh no gach
sath dhiudhiubh

Sid an coire cluinn an aona-bheoil
Cha do dh-fhag an aona-bheoil
Aona-mhir fuilich aig a ghoibhrich
Drollach air tota 'S fhireach air eigin
Eisde ri Duan na Druinnich
From the same at the same time

lg.l: NocNochd oichoidhch a chrochaidh chruaidh
Ceann (crann?) cruaidh ris na chriochadh Criosd
Criosda cleireach os ar cionn
Dh'orduich an Dia an duil a bhann
Is uasal bannag 's uasal bocnochd
Is uasal fear na h-oicheoidhche nocnochd
Bride chaidh air a glun
S e Righ uan Dul a bha na h-ucuchd
'S leir 'omh tulach (dhomh) 'S leir 'omh traigh
'S leir 'omh na fir air an t-snamh
'S leir 'omh calpa cruinn caol cruaidh
Tighinn air tir gu'n chairdeas ann
Is ioma taigh mor air an tulaichstulaich-s'
Gu'n fharmad duine ri cheile
Mise mac De leig is taigh mi
Criosda cleireach os ar cionn

div.p: From the same at the same time

lg.l: Mis an nocnochd a tighinn gar ionnsuidh
A dh urachadh dhuibh na Callaig
Cha ruig mi les a bhi ga innis
Bha i ann o linn ar seannar
Dhol deiseil an ardoruis
S teurnadh aig an dorus
Mo dhuan a gha'ail
Gu m odhail eolachmar a b aithne
Mo chaisein Callaig am phoca
S mor an ceo thig as an fhear ud
Rinidh fear an taighe na {lamhdhomdhomh air
Cuiridh i {cheannshron anns an teallach
Cuiridh i deiseil air na pairdeann e
S gu' seacseachd araidh air bean-an-taigh
Bean-an-taigh s i 's fhiach
Lamh a riarachadh na Callaig
Mar a bheil
Gum bith suil againn ri drama
Rud beag a thochar an t-samhraidh
Bha mi n geall air lus an aran
Mar bheil sid againn ri fhaotain
Ma dh-fhaodas sibh na cumaibh maill oirnn.

div.title: Ora Cniongain – Eolas Pronnaidh
div.p:
From Ranald Macdonald Gearruidh-na-moine
South Uist Aois 81. 3 FebyFebruary. 1874 A.AlexanderC.Carmichael

lg.l: An ora rinn Callum-cille
Ri (Do) chois a ghille 's a ghleann
Iocaidh an cneimhe lium (leam) deas
Iocaidh an cneimh deas lium (leam)
Iocam ma na tri iocann,
Mar a dh-iocadh a dh-Iosta Criosta
Nuair a chaidh Criost {air air a chroich
Bhrist cas an eich
Nuair thaine Criost gu lair (a mhan)
Rinn e slan a chas
Mar a rinn Criosta slan sin
Gu'n deanadh e slan so

A uc an Athar agus a Mhic
agus an Spioraid ghil {Naoimhchaoimh. Amen.
An t-eolas a rinn Calum-cille
Eir urlar a ghlinne
Do sgeith feithe s do leum cnamha
Tha thu tinn an diugh bith tu slan am maireach

div.note:
This is said three times, the thumb placed
against the sprain siachadh
div.p:
The operator blows his breath three times on the cniang –
an cniongan or pronnadh – either of which means
a bruise – There must be no broken skin. Old
Ranald vows that this prayer is efficatious in
healing the cniongan bruise only you must
have faith in it, for without faith he says that
the Ora is of no avail is no good. People come to him still
to say this ora over their infused limbs!

div.title: Eolas A Chronachaidh
div.p:
From Isiebeal Siosal Bana-cheard gun
aite fuirich gun aite dachaidh 8 May 1869.

lg.l: Buainidh mis a chathair aigh / charr
Mar a bhuain Criosda le 'laimh
Thainig ard righ nan aingeal
Gu h-ard fos mo chionn.
ThainiThainig Criosda steach
Le bliocbliochd le tlactlachd agus dair
Le laoigh bhoirionn le gras
Air suil bhig air suil mhoir
Air uacaruachdar cuid Chriosd
An ainm Dhia nan gras
Crun aigh nan aingeal
Bainne ugh s an carr
Le laoigh bhoirionn gun laugh firionn.
Gu robh agaibh fad nan seac bliadhna
Gu'n chall laoigh gu'n chall bainne.

div.p: From the same at the same time.

Dh-imich Criosda maille ra dheiscobuill
Agus thubhairt e Ciod an t ainm tha air
buaidh na lusa so?

'S e 'n t-ainm tha air buaidh na lusa so
An Dearg-bhasach (Dearg-chasach?)
Rois dheas Mhic De – agus a chois chlì.

div.title: Mōthan
div.p:
From Mary Stewart – "Mairi Bhreac" – 76, Malacleit
North Uist 19 March 1871 A.Alexander C.Carmichael

lg.l: Buainidh mis am Mō'an buadhar
An luibh is suairce a tha 's an tom
Dulagan nan seacseachd sagart
'S an agalaich a tha nan ceann - com
Gur liomsa an citheal {ciall 's an comhail
Fhad s a bhios {an luibh soam mothan agam 's gach am

div.title: Eolas A Chrannachain
div.p:
From Margaret Macdonald, 80, Howgearry, N.North Uist
25 NovNovember 1880

lg.l: Tha glug a seo tha glag a seo
Tha seilicheag mhor bhog a seo
Tha rud nach fhearr na sin an seo
Tha ceann an duine mhairbh an seo.

div.p:
This was said while churning and keeping
time with the loinid. Then when finishing and
lifting the loinid slowly up and down gathering
the butter she said: –

lg.l: Thuig a stōrm thuig
Thuig na meallain mora thuig,
Im gu uilinn blathach gu dōrna
Thuig an stōrm thuig

div.title: Staoin
div.p:
It is said that Staoin juniper was
placed in a ditch to enable Christ to pass
in safety – to form a sort of bridge – feithe.
Christ did pass in safety and when a horse
or cow hesitates in crossing a feithe a
sprig if only a sprig juniper gas strabh, sop is
placed in the ditch and the horse or other
beast passing crosses easily and willingly
gun ausadh (abhsadh) This is done
and believed in South Uist yet – 1888.

Mar a dh-orduich Mac an Lŭin
Stad air d-fhuil is ruith air t fhual.

The operator places the elbow to the tail
of the animal measuring lamh-choille
cubit till she gets to the mouth along
the back bone – spine.

lg.l: A Mhoire faic a bhean is i air fod a bhais

A Mhic o s ann agad a tha
Loisg a choinneal us baist an leanabh.

div.title: Hi Bhòligan
div.p:
From Mor Macphie (Mor Nic Fhraiseas (Francis) crofter
Baile Marbhath, IocharIochdar, SSouth Uist 18875, 22 OctOctober

lg.l: Hi bholigan bo nan aighean
Mo seacseachd chrochrodh laoigh us m aighean
An gach taobh an abhuinn
M' eudail thu 's tu chrochrodh na tire
Bheir thu am bainn air bhan na ciobe
Bheir thu am bainn air bhan na ciobe
S cha b'e uisge doin an t-siobain
Hi bholigan bo nan aighean
Clacha beaga treuna tioma
Do laogh fhein agus laogh ba eile
Fhaic thu fhein an druis air crionadh
'S an druis eile lan do smioran
S ionnan sin 'us m adhan goirri
'S a laogh boirionn air a bialtaobh
Tha loch anns a bheinn ud urrad (up)
Tha loch fiaraich ann tha loch liunn ann
Bu mhiann le m' adhan goirri
Bhi sior lianach loch abhainn
Us laogh na ba sin air chūl na beinne
Hi bhoiligan bo nan aighean
A bho dhubh sin 's a bho dhubh
S ionnan gatat dhomhs 'us dhuit
Thus a caoidh do cheud laoigh
S mise s mo mhac gaoil fo'n mhuin
Thoir am bainne bho dhonn
Thoir am bainne gu trom s gu tar'ach
Maraichean a tighinn an bhaile
S gu'n ann daibh ach an t-aran.
Ho m' adhan ho m' adhuin
Riaraich m adhan goirri
'S gabh ro d laogh.
Ceann na buaile bo gun laogh
Theid air burach bo gun laogh
Cha leig dachaidh bo gu'n laogh
Theid air chreacha bo gu'n laogh.
Cha tig dachaidh bo gu'n laogh
Theid air chreac ann bo gun laogh
Iomal buaile bo gu'n laogh
S leon a truaighead bo gun laogh

div.title: Eolas At Chioch

lg.l: Eolas a rinn Gillecalum
Air aona bho na caillich
Air ruaidh air at air dhair
Air na dealga sith
'S air na corracha cnamh.
Na ob e do dhuine
'S na diult e Di-domhnuich
An t-eolas a rinn Fionn (Fionn)
Ga dhearbh phiuthair

div.p:
Note – This is either to a woman or to
a cow.

div.title:
Bun Dearg {An Earna Dhearg}
{Kintail name}

lg.l: An t-eolas a rinn Calum-cille
Us leth chas sa churrachan
Sa leth chas eil air tir
Air a Bhun-dearg

note.p:
The Bun-dearg
is boiled and given in cream for the
Galar dearg.

div.title: Bun Dearg

lg.l: Air a ghalargein s air agach ghalar
A dh-fhaodas a bhi air a obhar duine no beothach
Sgruadadh a' d-fhuil, 's a d fhual, s d eirnean
Agus a d' feitheann s as do chnamhan.

div.p:
Note – Nine bottles of spring water is given three times
to a beast with the Bun Dearg. beside a well.

Lus an Deothain has griogagan beaga biteach
dearga ri taobh lochana beaga. Given to sickly
children. For what complaint? Worms?

Achlasan Chalum-chille like the Cairt leanna.
An Arneart is a small flat (glas-luibh) plant
given to beasts for the Bun Dearg.
Eointein = Flower upon a plant.

A grey plant (luibh ghlas) like the rǒid, bog
myrtle, causing Bun Dearg. Bun dearg is very
prevalent at Bogach na Fala, Iocar, when
the sundew is very abundant.

The splitting of the human hair at the point
is called gadmunn. The plant caledcalled the
Gadmunn prevents this hence the name.

No bog myrtle grows at IocarIochdar SSouth Uist
The luibh bheag ghlas like the myrtle grows
within at Bogach na Fala but no where
else at Iocar. A Chraobh-fo-dhealt = Sundew – Kintail name}

Tri-bhileach = Lus-nan-Laogh, used by
Medicinal Plants
girls and women. Meacunn is used for sac
and cuinng; The small one without
seed. The root of this is excellent for bringing
on child-birth – Fresh cream is given after.
Lus an driuc = Lus an deothail = Sundew.

div.title: Eolas Beum Sula
div.p:
Thainig distdithist a mach a dorust na cath-
rach neomh fear agus bean a [del: dheamh]
dheanamh nan oisnean. Beannaich
dha na fearaibh brunshuileach 's dha
na mnathann guir-shuileach agus
dha na ceithir saigheada fichead a
dh-fhaotadh a bhi n aor duine no
beothach.

B e Calumcille ard dhotair Alba
gu leigheas duine agus beothach.

lg.l: Teagasg a rinn bana-Bhride
Dha n mharaiche chrubach
Chaidh Criosd air each thaine Criosd ga chois
Thainig Criosda gu larmhan rinn e slan an chas t-each.

div.title: Eolais
div.p:
Place three knots on the string when putting the eolas
eolas in the snathaile

"Se Dia duileach a rinn e, fear na h-aibeide
big a mharbhadh agus fear a chota ghlais gun
aon dad air. So said the Highlander after kill-
ing a red-coat with his helmet on.

From Isebeil Shiosal, a bhana-cheard at Loch-
maddy, NNorth Uist 8th May 1869.

lg.l: Buainidh mise an Dearg-chreasachan
Mar a bhuain Criosda romh ghlaic
Air buaidh slainte agus buaidh toilleachaidh
Ths is for Droch Ruin.

div.title: Chloimh Chat – Eolas nan Caorach.
div.note:
See p 57
From the same woman of confused mind & memory.

lg.l: Buainidh mis a Chloimh Chat
Mar a bhuain Mathair Chriosda romh glaic
Air bhuar air] bhuaidh air bhleoghan
Air thuar 's air thoradh na laraich
Gu'n chall uan gu'n chall caora
An ainm an Athar agus a Mhic
Agus an Spioraid ghil {Naoimh{Naomha
